Layer-wise Adaptive Model Aggregation for Scalable Federated Learning

Sunwoo Lee, Tuo Zhang, Chaoyang He, Salman Avestimehr
Viterbi School of Engineering
University of Southern California
{sunwool,tuozhang,chaoyang.he,avestime}@usc.edu
Abstract

In Federated Learning, a common approach for aggregating local models across clients is periodic averaging of the full model parameters. It is, however, known that different layers of neural networks can have a different degree of model discrepancy across the clients. The conventional full aggregation scheme does not consider such a difference and synchronizes the whole model parameters at once, resulting in inefficient network bandwidth consumption. Aggregating the parameters that are similar across the clients does not make meaningful training progress while increasing the communication cost. We propose FedLAMA, a layer-wise model aggregation scheme for scalable Federated Learning. FedLAMA adaptively adjusts the aggregation interval in a layer-wise manner, jointly considering the model discrepancy and the communication cost. The layer-wise aggregation method enables to finely control the aggregation interval to relax the aggregation frequency without a significant impact on the model accuracy. Our extensive empirical study shows that, as the model aggregation interval increases, FedLAMA shows a significantly smaller accuracy drop than the periodic full aggregation scheme while achieving comparable communication efficiency.

1 Introduction

In Federated Learning, periodic full model aggregation is the most common approach for aggregating local models across clients. Many Federated Learning algorithms, such as FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al. (2017)), FedProx (Li etÂ al. (2018)), FedNova (Wang etÂ al. (2020)), and SCAFFOLD (Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020)), assume the underlying periodic full aggregation scheme. However, it has been observed that the magnitude of gradients can be significantly different across the layers of neural networks (You etÂ al. (2019)). That is, all the layers can have a different degree of model discrepancy. The periodic full aggregation scheme does not consider such a difference and synchronizes the entire model parameters at once. Aggregating the parameters that are similar across all the clients does not make meaningful training progress while increasing the communication cost. Considering the limited network bandwidth in usual Federated Learning environments, such an inefficient network bandwidth consumption can significantly harm the scalability of Federated Learning applications.

Many researchers have put much effort into addressing the expensive communication cost issue. Adaptive model aggregation methods adjust the aggregation interval to reduce the total communication cost (Wang and Joshi (2018); Haddadpour etÂ al. (2019)). Gradient (model) compression (Alistarh etÂ al. (2018); Albasyoni etÂ al. (2020)), sparsification (Wangni etÂ al. (2017); Wang etÂ al. (2018)), low-rank approximation (Vogels etÂ al. (2020); Wang etÂ al. (2021)), and quantization (Alistarh etÂ al. (2017); Wen etÂ al. (2017); Reisizadeh etÂ al. (2020)) techniques directly reduce the local data size. Employing heterogeneous model architectures across clients is also a communication-efficient approach (Diao etÂ al. (2020)). While all these works effectively tackle the expensive communication cost issue from different angles, they commonly assume the underlying periodic full model aggregation scheme.

To break such a convention of periodic full model aggregation, we propose FedLAMA, a novel layer-wise adaptive model aggregation scheme for scalable and accurate Federated Learning. FedLAMA first prioritizes all the layers based on their contributions to the total model discrepancy. We present a metric for estimating the layer-wise degree of model discrepancy at run-time. The aggregation intervals are adjusted based on the layer-wise model discrepancy such that the layers with a smaller degree of model discrepancy is assigned with a longer aggregation interval than the other layers. The above steps are repeatedly performed once the entire model is synchronized once.

Our focus is on how to relax the model aggregation frequency at each layer, jointly considering the communication efficiency and the impact on the convergence properties of federated optimization. By adjusting the aggregation interval based on the layer-wise model discrepancy, the local models can be effectively synchronized while reducing the number of communications at each layer. The model accuracy is marginally affected since the intervals are increased only at the layers that have the weakest contribution to the total model discrepancy. Our empirical study demonstrates that FedLAMA automatically finds the interval settings that make a practical trade-off between the communication cost and the model accuracy. We also provide a theoretical convergence analysis of FedLAMA for smooth and non-convex problems under non-IID data settings.

We evaluate the performance of FedLAMA across three representative image classification benchmark datasets: CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky etÂ al. (2009)), CIFAR-100, and Federated Extended MNIST (Cohen etÂ al. (2017)). Our experimental results deliver novel insights on how to aggregate the local models efficiently consuming the network bandwidth. Given a fixed training iteration budget, as the aggregation interval increases, FedLAMA shows a significantly smaller accuracy drop than the periodic full aggregation scheme while achieving comparable communication efficiency.

2 Related Works

Compression Methods â€“ The communication-efficient global model update methods can be categorized into two groups: structured update and sketched update (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al. (2016)). The structured update indicates the methods that enforce a pre-defined fixed structure of the local updates, such as low-rank approximation and random mask methods. The sketched update indicates the methods that post-process the local updates via compression, sparsification, or quantization. Both directions are well studied and have shown successful results (Alistarh etÂ al. (2018); Albasyoni etÂ al. (2020); Wangni etÂ al. (2017); Wang etÂ al. (2018); Vogels etÂ al. (2020); Wang etÂ al. (2021); Alistarh etÂ al. (2017); Wen etÂ al. (2017); Reisizadeh etÂ al. (2020)). The common principle behind these methods is that the local updates can be replaced with a different data representation with a smaller size.

These compression methods can be independently applied to our layer-wise aggregation scheme such that the each layerâ€™s local update is compressed before being aggregated. Since our focus is on adjusting the aggregation frequency rather than changing the data representation, we do not directly compare the performance between these two approaches. We leave harmonizing the layer-wise aggregation scheme and a variety of compression methods as a promising future work.

Similarity Scores â€“ Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA) methods are proposed to estimate the representational similarity across different models (Raghu etÂ al. (2017); Morcos etÂ al. (2018)). Centered Kernel Alignment (CKA) is an improved extension of CCA (Kornblith etÂ al. (2019)). While these methods effectively quantify the degree of similarity, they commonly require expensive computations. For example, SVCCA performs singular vector decomposition of the model and CKA computes Hilbert-Schmidt Independence Criterion multiple times (Gretton etÂ al. (2005)). In addition, the representational similarity does not deliver any information regarding the gradient difference that is strongly related to the convergence property. We will propose a practical metric for estimating the layer-wise model discrepancy, which is cheap enough to be used at run-time.

Layer-wise Model Freezing â€“ Layer freezing (dropping) is the representative layer-wise technique for neural network training (Brock etÂ al. (2017); Kumar etÂ al. (2019); Zhang and He (2020); Goutam etÂ al. (2020)). All these methods commonly stop updating the parameters of the layers in a bottom-up direction. These empirical techniques are supported by the analysis presented in (Raghu etÂ al. (2017)). Since the layers converge from the input-side sequentially, the layer-wise freezing can reduce the training time without strongly affecting the accuracy. These previous works clearly demonstrate the advantages of processing individual layers separately.

3 Background

Federated Optimization â€“ We consider federated optimization problems as follows.

minğ±âˆˆâ„dâ€‹[Fâ€‹(ğ±):=1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mFiâ€‹(ğ±)],ğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘delimited-[]assignğ¹ğ±1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ±\displaystyle\underset{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}{\min}\left[F(\mathbf{x}):=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}F_{i}(\mathbf{x})\right], (1)

where mğ‘šm is the number of local models (clients) and Fiâ€‹(ğ±)=ğ”¼Î¾iâˆ¼Di[Fiâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾i)]subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ±subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–subscriptğ·ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ±subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–F_{i}(\mathbf{x})=\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi_{i}\sim D_{i}}[F_{i}(\mathbf{x},\xi_{i})] is the local objective function associated with local data distribution Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}.

FedAvg is a basic algorithm that solves the above minimization problem. As the degree of data heterogeneity increases, FedAvg converges more slowly. Several variants of FedAvg, such as FedProx, FedNova, and SCAFFOLD, tackle the data heterogeneity issue. All these algorithms commonly aggregate the local solutions using the periodic full aggregation scheme.

Model Discrepancy â€“ All local SGD-based algorithms allow the clients to independently train their local models within each communication round. Thus, the variance of stochastic gradients and heterogeneous data distributions can lead the local models to different directions on parameter space during the local update steps. We formally define such a discrepancy among the models as follows.

1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€–ğ®âˆ’ğ±iâ€–2,1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptnormğ®superscriptğ±ğ‘–2\displaystyle\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\|\mathbf{u}-\mathbf{x}^{i}\|^{2},

where mğ‘šm is the number of local models (clients), ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} is the synchronized model, and ğ±isuperscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}^{i} is client iğ‘–iâ€™s local model. This quantity bounds the difference between the local gradients and the global gradients under a smoothness assumption on objective functions. Note that, even when the data is independent and identically distributed (IID), there always exist a certain degree of model discrepancy due to the variance of stochastic gradients.

4 Layer-wise Adaptive Model Aggregation

Layer Prioritization â€“ In theoretical analysis, it is common to assume the smoothness of objective functions such that the difference between local gradients and global gradients is bounded by a scaled difference of the corresponding sets of parameters. Motivated by this convention, we define â€˜layer-wise unit model discrepancyâ€™, a useful metric for prioritizing the layers as follows.

dl=1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€–ğ®lâˆ’ğ±liâ€–2Ï„lâ€‹(dimâ€‹(ğ®l)),lâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,L}formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘™1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ®ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘™ğ‘–2subscriptğœğ‘™dimsubscriptğ®ğ‘™ğ‘™1â‹¯ğ¿\displaystyle d_{l}=\frac{\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\|\mathbf{u}_{l}-\mathbf{x}_{l}^{i}\|^{2}}{\tau_{l}(\textrm{dim}(\mathbf{u}_{l}))},\hskip 14.22636ptl\in\{1,\cdots,L\} (2)

where Lğ¿L is the number of layers, lğ‘™l is the layer index, ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} is the global parameters, ğ±isuperscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}^{i} is the client iğ‘–iâ€™s local parameters, Ï„ğœ\tau is the aggregation interval, and dimâ€‹(â‹…)dimâ‹…\textrm{dim}(\cdot) is the number of parameters.

This metric quantifies how much each parameter contributes to the model discrepancy at each iteration. The communication cost is proportional to the number of parameters. Thus, 1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€–ğ®lâˆ’ğ±liâ€–2/dimâ€‹(ğ®l)1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ®ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘™ğ‘–2dimsubscriptğ®ğ‘™\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\|\mathbf{u}_{l}-\mathbf{x}_{l}^{i}\|^{2}/\textrm{dim}(\mathbf{u}_{l}) shows how much model discrepancy can be eliminated by synchronizing the layer at a unit communication cost. This metric allows prioritizing the layers such that the layers with a smaller dlsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘™d_{l} value has a lower priority than the others.

Adaptive Model Aggregation Algorithm â€“ We propose FedLAMA, a layer-wise adaptive model aggregation scheme. Algorithm 1 shows FedLAMA algorithm. There are two input parameters: Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} is the base aggregation interval and Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is the interval increase factor. First, the parameters at layer lğ‘™l are synchronized across the clients after every Ï„lsubscriptğœğ‘™\tau_{l} iterations (line 888). Then, the proposed metric dlsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘™d_{l} is calculated using the synchronized parameters ğ®lsubscriptğ®ğ‘™\mathbf{u}_{l} (line 777). At the end of every Ï•â€‹Ï„â€²italic-Ï•superscriptğœâ€²\phi\tau^{\prime} iterations, FedLAMA adjusts the model aggregation interval at all the Lğ¿L layers. (line 111111).

Algorithm 2 finds the layers that can be less frequently aggregated making a minimal impact on the total model discrepancy. First, the layer-wise degree of model discrepancy is estimated as follows.

Î´l=âˆ‘i=1ld^iâˆ—dimâ€‹(ğ®i)âˆ‘i=1Ld^iâˆ—dimâ€‹(ğ®i),subscriptğ›¿ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘™subscript^ğ‘‘ğ‘–dimsubscriptğ®ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¿subscript^ğ‘‘ğ‘–dimsubscriptğ®ğ‘–\displaystyle\delta_{l}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{l}\hat{d}_{i}*\textrm{dim}(\mathbf{u}_{i})}{\sum_{i=1}^{L}\hat{d}_{i}*\textrm{dim}(\mathbf{u}_{i})}, (3)

where d^isubscript^ğ‘‘ğ‘–\hat{d}_{i} is the itâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡â„i^{th} smallest element in the sorted list of the proposed metric dğ‘‘d. Given lğ‘™l layers with the smallest dlsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘™d_{l} values, Î´lsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘™\delta_{l} quantifies their contribution to the total model discrepancy. Second, the communication cost impact is estimated as follows.

Î»l=âˆ‘i=1ldimâ€‹(ğ®i)âˆ‘i=1Ldimâ€‹(ğ®i)subscriptğœ†ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘™dimsubscriptğ®ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¿dimsubscriptğ®ğ‘–\displaystyle\lambda_{l}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{l}\textrm{dim}({\mathbf{u}_{i}})}{\sum_{i=1}^{L}\textrm{dim}({\mathbf{u}_{i}})} (4)

Î»lsubscriptğœ†ğ‘™\lambda_{l} is the ratio of the parameters at the lğ‘™l layers with the smallest dlsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘™d_{l} values. Thus, 1âˆ’Î»l1subscriptğœ†ğ‘™1-\lambda_{l} estimates the number of parameters that will be more frequently synchronized than the others. As lğ‘™l increases, Î´lsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘™\delta_{l} increases while 1âˆ’Î»l1subscriptğœ†ğ‘™1-\lambda_{l} decreases monotonically. Algorithm 2 loops over the Lğ¿L layers finding the lğ‘™l value that makes Î´lsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘™\delta_{l} and 1âˆ’Î»l1subscriptğœ†ğ‘™1-\lambda_{l} similar. In this way, it finds the aggregation interval setting that slightly sacrifices the model discrepancy while remarkably reducing the communication cost.

Figure 1 shows the Î´lsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘™\delta_{l} and 1âˆ’Î»l1subscriptğœ†ğ‘™1-\lambda_{l} curves collected from a) CIFAR-10 (ResNet20) training and b) CIFAR-100 (Wide-ResNet28-10) training. The x-axis is the number of layers to increase the aggregation interval and the y-axis is the Î´lsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘™\delta_{l} and 1âˆ’Î»l1subscriptğœ†ğ‘™1-\lambda_{l} values. The cross point of the two curves is much lower than 0.50.50.5 on y-axis in both charts. For instance, in Figure 1.a), the two curves are crossed when xğ‘¥x value is 999, and the corresponding yğ‘¦y value is near 0.20.20.2. That is, when the aggregation interval is increased at those 999 layers, 20%percent2020\% of the total model discrepancy will increase by a factor of Ï•italic-Ï•\phi while 80%percent8080\% of the total communication cost will decrease by the same factor. Note that the cross points are below 0.50.50.5 since the Î´lsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘™\delta_{l} and 1âˆ’Î»l1subscriptğœ†ğ‘™1-\lambda_{l} are calculated using the dlsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘™d_{l} values sorted in an increasing order.

It is worth noting that FedLAMA can be easily extended to improve the convergence rate at the cost of having minor extra communications. In this work, we do not consider finding such interval settings because it can increase the latency cost, which is not desired in Federated Learning. However, in the environments where the latency cost can be ignored, such as high-performance computing platforms, FedLAMA can accelerate the convergence by adjusting the intervals based on the cross point of 1âˆ’Î´l1subscriptğ›¿ğ‘™1-\delta_{l} and Î»lsubscriptğœ†ğ‘™\lambda_{l} calculated using the list of dlsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘™d_{l} values sorted in a decreasing order.

Impact of Aggregation Interval Increasing Factor Ï•italic-Ï•\phi â€“ In Federated Learning, the communication latency cost is usually not negligible, and the total number of communications strongly affects the scalability. When increasing the aggregation interval, Algorithm 2 multiplies a pre-defined small constant Ï•italic-Ï•\phi to the fixed base interval Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} (line 10). This approach ensures that the communication latency cost is not increased while the network bandwidth consumption is reduced by a factor of Ï•italic-Ï•\phi.

FedAvg can be considered as a special case of FedLAMA where Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is set to 111. When Ï•>1italic-Ï•1\phi>1, FedLAMA less frequently synchronize a subset of layers, and it results in reducing their communication costs. When increasing the aggregation interval, FedLAMA multiplies Ï•italic-Ï•\phi to the base interval Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime}. So, it is guaranteed that the whole model parameters are fully synchronized after every Ï•â€‹Ï„â€²italic-Ï•superscriptğœâ€²\phi\tau^{\prime} iterations. Because of the layers with the base aggregation interval Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime}, the total model discrepancy of FedLAMA after Ï•â€‹Ï„â€²italic-Ï•superscriptğœâ€²\phi\tau^{\prime} iterations is always smaller than that of FedAvg with an interval of Ï•â€‹Ï„â€²italic-Ï•superscriptğœâ€²\phi\tau^{\prime}.

Theorem 5.3.

1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1ğ”¼[â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ®t)â€–2]1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ®ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathop{\mathbb{E}}\left[\left\|\nabla F(\mathbf{u}_{t})\right\|^{2}\right] â‰¤4Î·â€‹Ï„â€‹Tâ€‹(Fâ€‹(ğ®0)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ®âˆ—))+2â€‹Lâ€‹Î·mâ€‹Ïƒ2+3â€‹Tâ€‹L2â€‹Î·2â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)â€‹Ïƒ2+6â€‹Î·2â€‹L2â€‹Ï„â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)â€‹Îº2absent4ğœ‚ğœğ‘‡ğ¹subscriptğ®0ğ¹subscriptğ®2ğ¿ğœ‚ğ‘šsuperscriptğœ23ğ‘‡superscriptğ¿2superscriptğœ‚2ğœ1superscriptğœ26superscriptğœ‚2superscriptğ¿2ğœğœ1superscriptğœ…2\displaystyle\leq\frac{4}{\eta\tau T}\left(F(\mathbf{u}_{0})-F(\mathbf{u}_{*})\right)+\frac{2L\eta}{m}\sigma^{2}+3TL^{2}\eta^{2}(\tau-1)\sigma^{2}+6\eta^{2}L^{2}\tau(\tau-1)\kappa^{2} (6)

Remark 1. (Linear Speedup) With a sufficiently small diminishing learning rate and a large number of training iterations, FedLAMA achieves linear speedup. If the learning rate is Î·=mTğœ‚ğ‘šğ‘‡\eta=\frac{\sqrt{m}}{\sqrt{T}}, we have

ğ”¼[1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ®t)â€–2]ğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ®ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\mathop{\mathbb{E}}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{u}_{t})\|^{2}\right] â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(1mâ€‹T)+ğ’ªâ€‹(mT)absentğ’ª1ğ‘šğ‘‡ğ’ªğ‘šğ‘‡\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{mT}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{m}{T}\right) (7)

If T>m3ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘š3T>m^{3}, the first term on the right-hand side becomes dominant and it achieves linear speedup.

Remark 2. (Impact of Interval Increase Factor Ï•italic-Ï•\phi) The worst-case model discrepancy depends on the largest averaging interval across all the layers, Ï„=Ï•â€‹Ï„â€²ğœitalic-Ï•superscriptğœâ€²\tau=\phi\tau^{\prime}. The larger the interval increase factor Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, the larger the model discrepancy terms in (6). In the meantime, as Ï•italic-Ï•\phi increases, the communication frequency at the selected layers is proportionally reduced. So, Ï•italic-Ï•\phi should be appropriately tuned to effectively reduce the communication cost while not much increasing the model discrepancy.

6 Experiments

Experimental Settings â€“ We evaluate FedLAMA using three representative benchmark datasets: CIFAR-10 (ResNet20 (He etÂ al. (2016))), CIFAR-100 (WideResNet28-10 (Zagoruyko and Komodakis (2016))), and Federated Extended MNIST (CNN (Caldas etÂ al. (2018))). We use TensorFlow 2.4.3 for local training and MPI for model aggregation. All our experiments are conducted on 4 compute nodes each of which has 2 NVIDIA v100 GPUs.

Due to the limited compute resources, we simulate Federated Learning such that each process sequentially trains multiple models and then the models are aggregated across all the processes at once. While it provides the same classification results as the actual Federated Learning, the training time is serialized within each process. Thus, instead of wall-clock time, we consider the total communication cost calculated as follows.

ğ’=âˆ‘l=1Lğ’l=âˆ‘l=1Ldimâ€‹(ğ®l)âˆ—Îºl,ğ’superscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ¿subscriptğ’ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ¿dimsubscriptğ®ğ‘™subscriptğœ…ğ‘™\displaystyle\mathcal{C}=\sum_{l=1}^{L}\mathcal{C}_{l}=\sum_{l=1}^{L}\textrm{dim}(\mathbf{u}_{l})*\kappa_{l}, (8)

where Îºlsubscriptğœ…ğ‘™\kappa_{l} is the total number of communications at layer lğ‘™l during the training.

Hyper-Parameter Settings â€“ We use 128128128 clients in our experiments. The local batch size is set to 323232 and the learning rate is tuned based on a grid search. For CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, we artificially generate heterogeneous data distributions using Dirichletâ€™s distribution. When using Non-IID data, we also consider partial device participation such that randomly chosen 25%percent2525\% of the clients participate in training at every Ï•â€‹Ï„â€²italic-Ï•superscriptğœâ€²\phi\tau^{\prime} iterations. We report the average accuracy across at least three separate runs.

6.1 Classification Performance Analysis

We compare the performance across three different model aggregation settings as follows.

  • â€¢

    Periodic full aggregation with an interval of Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime}

  • â€¢

    Periodic full aggregation with an interval of Ï•â€‹Ï„â€²italic-Ï•superscriptğœâ€²\phi\tau^{\prime}

  • â€¢

    Layer-wise adaptive aggregation with intervals of Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} and Ï•italic-Ï•\phi

The first setting provides the baseline communication cost, and we compare it to the other settingsâ€™ communication costs. The third setting is FedLAMA with the base aggregation interval Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} and the interval increase factor Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. Due to the limited space, we present a part of experimental results that deliver the key insights. More results can be found in Appendix.

Experimental Results with IID Data â€“ We first present CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 classification results under IID data settings. Table 1 and 2 show the CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 results, respectively. Note that the learning rate is individually tuned for each setting using a grid search, and we report the best settings. In both tables, the first row shows the performance of FedAvg with a short interval Ï„â€²=6superscriptğœâ€²6\tau^{\prime}=6. As the interval increases, FedAvg significantly loses the accuracy while the communication cost is proportionally reduced. FedLAMA achieves a comparable accuracy to FedAvg with Ï„â€²=6superscriptğœâ€²6\tau^{\prime}=6 while its communication cost is similar to that of FedAvg with Ï•â€‹Ï„â€²italic-Ï•superscriptğœâ€²\phi\tau^{\prime}. These results demonstrate that Algorithm 2 effectively finds the layer-wise interval settings that maximize the communication cost reduction while minimizing the model discrepancy increase.

Experimental Results with Non-IID Data â€“ We now evaluate the performance of FedLAMA using non-IID data. FEMNIST is inherently heterogeneous such that it contains the hand-written digit pictures collected from 3,55035503,550 different writers. We use random 10%percent1010\% of the writersâ€™ training samples in our experiments. Table 3 shows the FEMNIST classification results. The base interval Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} is set to 101010. FedAvg (Ï•=1italic-Ï•1\phi=1) significantly loses the accuracy as the aggregation interval increases. For example, when the interval increases from 101010 to 404040, the accuracy is dropped by 2.1%âˆ¼2.7%similar-topercent2.1percent2.72.1\%\sim 2.7\%. In contrast, FedLAMA maintains the accuracy when Ï•italic-Ï•\phi increases, while the communication cost is remarkably reduced. This result demonstrates that FedLAMA effectively finds the best interval setting that reduces the communication cost while maintaining the accuracy.

Table 4 and 5 show the non-IID CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 experimental results. We use Dirichletâ€™s distribution to generate heterogeneous data across all the clients. The base aggregation interval Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} is set to 666. The interval increase factor Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is set to 222 for FedLAMA. Likely to the IID data experiments, we observe that the periodic full averaging significantly loses the accuracy as the model aggregation interval increases, while it has a proportionally reduced communication cost. FedLAMA achieves the comparable classification performance to the periodic full averaging, regardless of the device activation ratio and the degree of data heterogeneity. For CIFAR-100, FedLAMA has a minor accuracy drop compared to the periodic full averaging with Ï„â€²=6superscriptğœâ€²6\tau^{\prime}=6, however, the accuracy is still much higher than the periodic full averaging with Ï„â€²=12superscriptğœâ€²12\tau^{\prime}=12. For both datasets, FedLAMA has a remarkably reduced communication cost compared to the periodic full averaging with Ï„â€²=6superscriptğœâ€²6\tau^{\prime}=6.

6.2 Communication Efficiency Analysis

We analyze the total number of communications and the accumulated data size to evaluate the communication efficiency of FedLAMA. Figure 2 shows the total number of communications at the individual layers. The Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} is set to 666 and Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is 2 for FedLAMA. The key insight is that FedLAMA increases the aggregation interval mostly at the output-side large layers. This means the dlsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘™d_{l} value shown in Equation (2) at the these layers are smaller than the others. Since these large layers take up most of the total model parameters, the communication cost is remarkably reduced when their aggregation intervals are increased. Figure 3 shows the layer-wise local data size shown in Equation 8. FedLAMA shows the significantly smaller total data size than FedAvg. The extra computational cost of FedLAMA is almost negligible since it calculates dlsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘™d_{l} after each communication round only. Therefore, given the virtually same computational cost, FedLAMA aggregates the local models at a cheaper communication cost, and thus it improves the scalablity of Federated Learning.

We found that the amount of the reduced communication cost was not strongly affected by the degree of data heterogeneity. As shown in Table 4 and 5, the reduced communication cost is similar across different Dirichletâ€™s coefficients and device participation ratios. That is, FedLAMA can be considered as an effective model aggregation scheme regardless of the degree of data heterogeneity.

7 Conclusion

We proposed a layer-wise model aggregation scheme that adaptively adjusts the model aggregation interval at run-time. Breaking the convention of aggregating the whole model parameters at once, this novel model aggregation scheme introduces a flexible communication strategy for scalable Federated Learning. Furthermore, we provide a solid convergence guarantee of FedLAMA under the assumptions on the non-convex objective functions and the non-IID data distribution. Our empirical study also demonstrates the efficacy of FedLAMA for scalable and accurate Federated Learning. Harmonizing FedLAMA with other advanced optimizers, gradient compression, and low-rank approximation methods is a promising future work.

Lemma 5.2. (model discrepancy) Under Assumption 1âˆ¼4similar-to141\sim 4, Algorithm 1 ensures

1mâ€‹âˆ‘j=0Ï„âˆ’1âˆ‘i=1mğ”¼[â€–ğ±t,jiâˆ’ğ®tâ€–2]â‰¤Î·2â€‹Ï„â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)1âˆ’Aâ€‹Ïƒ2+Ï„â€‹Aâ€‹Î²2(1âˆ’A)â€‹L2â€‹ğ”¼[â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ®t)â€–2]+Ï„â€‹Aâ€‹Îº2(1âˆ’A)â€‹L2,1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—0ğœ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘šğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ®ğ‘¡2superscriptğœ‚2ğœğœ11ğ´superscriptğœ2ğœğ´superscriptğ›½21ğ´superscriptğ¿2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ®ğ‘¡2ğœğ´superscriptğœ…21ğ´superscriptğ¿2\displaystyle\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=0}^{\tau-1}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\mathop{\mathbb{E}}\left[\left\|\mathbf{x}_{t,j}^{i}-\mathbf{u}_{t}\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\frac{\eta^{2}\tau(\tau-1)}{1-A}\sigma^{2}+\frac{\tau A\beta^{2}}{(1-A)L^{2}}\mathop{\mathbb{E}}\left[\left\|\nabla F(\mathbf{u}_{t})\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{\tau A\kappa^{2}}{(1-A)L^{2}}, (20)

where Aâ‰”2â€‹Î·2â€‹L2â€‹Ï„â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)<1â‰”ğ´2superscriptğœ‚2superscriptğ¿2ğœğœ11A\coloneqq 2\eta^{2}L^{2}\tau(\tau-1)<1.

Proof.

The worst-case model discrepancy comes from the case where Algorithm 1 increases the aggregation interval at all the layers. That is, the aggregation interval at every layer is Ï„=Ï„â€²â€‹Ï•ğœsuperscriptğœâ€²italic-Ï•\tau=\tau^{\prime}\phi. Considering such a worst-case discrepancy, the total model discrepancy at a local step jğ‘—j in communication round tğ‘¡t is bounded as follows.

where (25) holds based on Assumption 4. This complete the proof. âˆ

A.2 Additional Experimental Results

In this section, we provide extra experimental results with extensive hyper-parameter settings. We fix the number of clients to 128128128 and use a local batch size of 323232 in all the experiments. The gradual learning rate warm-up (Goyal etÂ al. [2017]) is applied to the first 10 epochs. Overall, the learning curve charts and the validation accuracy tables deliver the key insight that FedLAMA achieves a comparable convergence speed to the periodic full aggregation with the base interval (Ï„ğœ\tauâ€™) while having the communication cost that is similar to the periodic full aggregation with the increased interval (Ï•â€‹Ï„â€²italic-Ï•superscriptğœâ€²\phi\tau^{\prime}).

Artificial Data Heterogeneity â€“ For CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, we artificially generate the heterogeneous data distribution using Dirichletâ€™s distribution. The concentration coefficient Î±ğ›¼\alpha is set to 0.10.10.1, 0.50.50.5, and 1.01.01.0 to evaluate the performance of FedLAMA across a variety of degree of data heterogeneity. Note that the small concentration coefficient represents the highly heterogeneous numbers of local samples across clients as well as the balance of the samples across the labels. We used the data distribution source code provided by FedML (He etÂ al. [2020]).

CIFAR-10 â€“ Figure 4 shows the full learning curves for IID and non-IID CIFAR-10 datasets. The hyper-parameter settings correspond to Table 4 and 1. First, as the aggregation interval increases from 666 to 242424, FedAvg suffers from the slower convergence, and it results in achieving a lower validation accuracy, regardless of the data distribution. In contrast, FedLAMA learning curves are marginally affected by the increased aggregation interval. Table 6 and 7 show the CIFAR-10 classification performance of FedLAMA across different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi settings. As expected, the accuracy is reduced as Ï•italic-Ï•\phi increases. The IID and non-IID data settings show the common trend. Depending on the system network bandwidth, Ï•italic-Ï•\phi can be tuned to be an appropriate value. When Ï•=2italic-Ï•2\phi=2, the accuracy is almost the same as or even slightly higher than FedAvg accuracy. If the network bandwidth is limited, one can increase Ï•italic-Ï•\phi and slightly increase the epoch budget to achieve a good accuracy. Table 8 shows the CIFAR-10 accuracy across different Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} settings. We see that the accuracy is significantly dropped as Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} increases.

CIFAR-100 â€“ Figure 5 shows the learning curves for IID and non-IID CIFAR-100 datasets. Likely to CIFAR-10 results, FedAvg learning curves are strongly affected as the aggregation interval increases from 666 to 242424 while FedLAMA learning curves are not strongly affected. Table 9 and 10 show the CIFAR-100 classification performance of FedLAMA across different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi settings. FedLAMA achieves a comparable accuracy to FedAvg with a short aggregation interval, even when the degree of data heterogeneity is extreamly high (25%percent2525\% device sampling and Direchletâ€™s coefficient of 0.10.10.1). Table 11 shows the FedAvg accuracy with different Ï„â€²superscriptğœâ€²\tau^{\prime} settings. Under the strongly heterogeneous data distributions, FedAvg with a large aggregation interval (Ï„â‰¥12ğœ12\tau\geq 12) do not achieve a reasonable accuracy.

FEMNIST â€“ Figure 6 shows the learning curves of CNN training. Likely to the previous two datasets, the periodic full aggregation suffers from the slower convergence as the aggregation interval increases. FedLAMA learning curves are not much affected by the increased aggregation interval, and it results in achieving a higher validation accuracy after the same number of iterations. Table 12 shows the FEMNIST classification performance of FedLAMA across different Ï•italic-Ï•\phi settings. FedLAMA achieves a similar accuracy to the baseline (FedAvg with Ï„â€²=10superscriptğœâ€²10\tau^{\prime}=10) even when using a large interval increase factor Ï•â‰¥4italic-Ï•4\phi\geq 4. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed layer-wise adaptive model aggregation method on the problems with heterogeneous data distributions.
